file_content.text: This is station comm control. Routing a message from Darth Marr.
Lord Wrath, this is station comm control. We have a message on your frequency from Darth Marr.
Dark Lord, this is station comm control. Priority message for you from Darth Marr.
This is station comm control. We have an incoming transmission from Darth Marr--your identity isn't on file, but the computer thinks you're authorized to decrypt....
Put it through and erase any record from your comm log.
Hunter. This is station comm control--we have a priority message from Darth Marr.
Put it through.
No niceties today, Wrath. My time is short.
No politics today. My time is short.
I have little time, so I ask you to listen.
Too many betrayers have attempted to seize power of late. Darth Malgus's men are finished, but the Dread Masters endure.
Since you freed them on Belsavis, their madness has driven them to conquest. A dozen systems have fallen; you've seen their power.
I killed one on Darvannis. I know what they're capable of.
Since you freed them on Belsavis, their madness has driven them to conquest. We slew one on the planet Darvannis, yet five remain.
I take it something has changed?
They were the Emperor's favored servants, yet idolized fear above the Empire. Now we have found their fortress on Oricon, a remote moon.
When the Emperor went silent, the Dread Masters should have bowed to me. Now they will have no choice.
They will soon obey my power.
There is no loyalty in their hearts.
Power such as theirs cannot be contained. It rises until obliterated, as you well know.
Their betrayal was inevitable.
Their insanity goes too far. It breeds destruction, not glory.
How did you expose them? And what brought them to that moon?
Why Oricon? Why now?
Interrogation of a Dread Guard revealed the truth, but we know little of the moon itself.
I've met a lot of crazy Sith--the Dread Masters are something else altogether. This moon is their base?
They're a bunch of lunatics.
We are certain.
The Masters are still Sith. Seeing they've lost, they might rejoin the Empire--or at least submit to a superior force.
Any chance they may surrender?
The time for diplomacy is past, and the superiority of our force remains to be seen.
If we know where they are, it's time to turn that moon into dust. Or have things soured already?
Then don't wait to attack.
The Republic moved before we did, sending a full fleet to Oricon. Its armada was undone by the Masters' powers of fear and madness.
Our task force followed--a rapid strike deployment led by one Lord Hargrev, upon the insistence of Darth Rictus.
Hargrev is a braggart and a sadist, but he has studied our foe. He believed that he and his acolytes could shield our task force from the Masters' power.
Why do I suspect Hargrev overestimated himself?
Let me guess: He was wrong.
I've never heard of Hargrev. Where's he come from? What's he really capable of?
What's Hargrev's background?
He studied under Lord Silthar; had he spent less time in his "agony dungeon," he might have become a Darth long ago.
Given my experience with the enemy, why wasn't I consulted about your task force?
I should have been informed.
You were needed elsewhere, and military decisions are mine to make. But... I may have been in error.
I have heard nothing since Hargrev's ships arrived in-system twelve hours ago. Either his forces were defeated... or Hargrev has betrayed us.
Either way, the Dread Masters will sense weakness and counterattack. I have no forces to spare--you represent our last chance to stop them.
I don't have an army at the ready, Lord Marr. What exactly do you want?
What are you asking of me?
You presume I desire to mend your mistakes. But that is not my role.
I am not your weapon to wield.
Challenge me before the council if you wish. But turn away, and Korriban itself may burn.
I am your equal on the Dark Council, Lord Marr. I may have other affairs to attend to.
You assume too much of me.
These matters threaten our very survival. Besides--I expect you will seize the chance to uncover the Masters' secrets.
If you need my resources to protect the Empire, you'll have them. But don't treat me as a mindless assassin.
I'm not your thug, Marr.
If you have operatives capable of infiltrating enemy territory, send them. My interest is not in our egos, but our survival.
It's your money--but if I spent as much time hunting Jedi as I did your kind, you might be winning this war.
I seem to kill a lot of Sith.
I agree.
I freed the Dread Masters. They never did show gratitude. Why shouldn't I be the one to stop them?
I have a score to settle.
Even you cannot slay the Masters singlehandedly. If you can reach Oricon, however, you may find some remnant of Hargrev's task force.
If all else fails... send any warning you can of the Dread Masters' strengths. Perhaps then we can limit our losses to mere sectors.
Very well. Forward whatever data you have and await my word.
Best of luck to you.
There are no incoming messages at this time.
Since their... release from Belsavis, their madness has driven them to conquest. A dozen systems have fallen; you've seen their power.
Since their... release from Belsavis, their madness has driven them to conquest. We slew one on the planet Darvannis, yet five remain.
All right. Forward whatever data you've got and wait for my signal.
I will make sure the Dread Masters' treason ends now.
It will be done.
Dread Masters = defeated // D5-F2 = in awe of you
Oricon operations = ongoing
D5-F2 = unable to find incoming messages // You = try again later
Important message = incoming // You = please stand by....
